ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

Elyssa Gelmann and Fauna Samuel
Elissa&Fauna

Elyssa Gelman @ Fauna Samuel

Elyssa Gelman and Fauna Samuel

Fauna and Elyssa

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Shimi is a fantastic, caring, thorough professor. There's a lot of material, which can make it hard to follow without a chemistry background, but he tries hard to make it accessible to everyone and makes himself available for a lot of extra help and office hours.

One of the best professors I ever had. Very challenging material and the professor went way above and beyond anything that most professors do to make sure we all understood everything. Lots of office hours. Lots of assessment and feedback. Very clear notes to help us review material.

The course was very dense with information and moved quickly. This sometimes meant not all concepts were clear or easy to grasp orally, especially for those without a chemistry background, but Shimi does an excellent job of assisting with that by providing written notes and outlines for each class that really help fill in the blanks.
This class was my favorite at FES so far (in 1 year).

-Great course, Shimi makes himself very available and accessible to students by holding biweekly office hours/problem set sessions. Most professors would just have the TA's do these sessions with students, but Shimi really takes a hands on approach and wants students to understand the material. He goes above and beyond most professors - holds a session at the beginning of the term for students who do not have background in organic chemistry, and is very responsive, always happy to explain concepts, make time, etc.-overall very impressed with teaching and the material.

Any student working on water MUST take this class. Otherwise, it is an excellent course to anyone interested in pollution and fate of those pollutants especially organic one.Shimi is an excellent instructor even non chem-lovers would love the class

I loved this class. I have no intention on working with anything that we talked about, but I really, truly loved this class, and looked forward to it every week (maybe except the week where we had evening make up sessions - but then I looked forward to Modern Pizza! Thanks again!)This class opened up the previously mysterious world of organic chemistry to me. I will probably never take a full o-chem class, but this class was perfect because it combined the basic principles I'll need for any other engagement with organic chemistry, with an extremely interesting subject matter, and lots of applications to real problems.I think this is a unique class - advanced yet open to beginners, fast paced and challenging, but with a very kind and understanding and EXTREMELY well organized instructor, and it's fun!
This course is excellent. It fills a very important need in the curriculum: science course, chemistry, both pure and applied science, portions are most likely considered advanced.
Real science! And really interesting to learn the history of various chemical interactions with society, like Exxon Valdez and the GM PCB spill.
The instructor explained everything carefully and made sure everyone was following especially when it came to the more difficult concepts. He was well organized and covered interesting material.
Learning how these things work in the natural environment.
Learning lots of very complicated scientific information in a clear, concise, straightforward manner. Learning how to apply this science to relevant environmental issues and situations.
The extensive knowledge of the instructor about the topic, and his patience with us.
The problem sets! Essential to understanding the concepts taught in class. Shimi is a great teacher.
-professor-problem sets - actually makes you learn the material without getting behind, having weekly problem sets keeps students on tracks, lets the material solidify, etc
Shimi is a wonderful professor and an absolute joy to take a class from! I loved this course and the topics we covered were really interesting.

I felt that I left this class with a good understanding of basic organic chemistry and was given a clear overview of some of the more persistent pollutants. I learned far more in this class than I have in many others at FES.
Puts real life events (pollutants transfer& transformation and their effect on us) in to perspective

The instructor. Shimi is great and one of a few professors at FES who makes himself available to students to an amazing degree. I don't know what other professor here hold open drop-in office hours, twice a week, plus multiple review sessions, and a model building session. And a chemistry review session. That's the kind of thing that most professors make their TA do, but we learned to much more from him that way. I was amazed that Shimi continued to show up to most of his office hours, and all of his classes and review sessions, even when his father was in hospital at the end of the semester. Unheard of.He also has seemingly never-ending patience for answering the exact same question about the problem set over and over again during office hours, and is very good at explaining complex matters simply. He also has thefacility to make some of the most obscure tidbits interesting. The only part of the class where I had a hard time paying attention was the part on sampling and data analysis - but then that's just very dry.I really liked the resources provided for the class - a very good mix of textbook, general articles, primary literature, and of course the class notes - INVALUABLE.One of our little group of non-chemistry people in the class told me that she ended up having to answer all the questions that came up in her risk assessment class at Public Health about octane ratings, fractional distillation, the formation of petroleum, and what the problem with MTBE is - no one else knew the right answer, so she ended up speaking up every time, even though she is very quiet usually. Then the professor asked her if she had a chemistry background - anything but, but after learning about these things in this class, she knew enough and was confident enough to answer all these questions without reviewing notes or preparing. She was very proud. And I've lost count of how many basic questions I've been fielding about oil spill clean up - I feel very very well educated after taking this class, and I sincerely hope that other students have a chance to take this class next year- I've been recommending it to everyone, whether they're interested in this subject matter or not... I'm not really, and I loved it.

Shimi. He's the best teacher I had at FES. The topic is also incredibly interesting, the work is useful and interesting. It was the hardest class I took at FES, but I was more motivated to work hard for this class then any other.
The organization of the material. It was very easy to understand what we were covering and how it fit into the overall organization of the course.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I wish we had talked a little more about policy, how TMDLs and other regulations are set, a bit more on toxicology, and chemical interactions. But I don't know when we would have had time for these things.
I don't think it needs improvement.

I'm not sure Shimi was able to cover all the material he would have liked to due to a discrepancy between the start time listed for graduates and undergraduates. This could be addressed so that both may continue to take the course.It also would have been nice to spend a bit more time on the applications of organic pollutants: i.e. consequences of pesticide use, health risks etc. though the intro we had was very helpful.
May be a more useful textbook. I don't know if it exists. Shimi said he would need to write one.
Perhaps one additional lab/field trip to help visualize pollutant compartmentalization.
The field trip wasn't the best, but that was still fine. Overall, a wonderful class!
Nothing really, although I would recommend not have problem sets due the same week of tests.

It would be nice to have the historical background and numbers on the impact to say people so when someone is talking of policy one can talk with authority on not just the effects but also eg of impacts

Hm - the problem sets were really helpful in understanding the material, and I'm very happy they ended eventually, but I think they might have actually been really helpful to have for the final weeks as well - less quantitative, more qualitative of course, or some analysis of degradation pathways and toxicity of some of the pollutants we discussed?
It's got to be incredibly difficult to decide what stays and what goes in terms of material covered in this course, but the amount of material covered makes it difficult to achieve mastery with it.
Leave more time for the material at the end of the semester--the discussion of classes of pollutants. Also I would like to have spent more time on remediation.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Terrific. I really haven't gone to the TAs at all because Shimi was so available with help on problem sets.
They were all approachable, helpful and made themselves as available as possible.
They were all very available.
Instructors extra office hour sessions were always helpful and very necessary for learning new concepts.Two TAs: Elyssa was especially helpful at explaining concepts and problem sets.
Great. They were always available.
Shimi is very available to help students - he keeps multiple office hours throughout the week.
discussed for professor above in question 10TA's were very responsive and held weekly office hours, helpful, accessible.
Shimi provides several office hours every week to help students with the assignments or to just help clarify what he's teaching in class. The TAs were also available and generally helpful.
Very available
As decribed above, Shimi is amazingly available and incredibly helpful.I had class during Fauna's office hours, but when I got up in time for Elyssa's, she was very helpful!

Elyssa was particularly helpful and patient. Both TAs made themselves very available. Shimi went above and beyond (and beyond again) in terms of making himself available. I couldn't believe how much of his time he devoted to us and to this course.
Excellent availability and quality of help by the instructor.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: It gives me a grounding in the types of pollutants I might find in water. I'm interested in water and wetland policy, so this is very relevant.

FES has very classes that speak to environmental justice concerns, this class is directly relevant and very useful to anyone looking at the environmental consequences of our actions and how to work towards more sustainable communities. This helped me to understand the chemical processes at work behind the issues communities deal with in their daily lives.
This course helped me differentiate the organic pollutants found in water. I understand much better how chemical structure makes something a more persistent pollutant.
This course was a great addition to other classes as I got to focus on a specific type of pollutant.

Sure does, interest in water cannot ignore pollution. It is important to know how you are dealing with, the best mitigation measures for the different pollutants to achieve the ultimate success in the mitigation

It doesn't really - but I felt that I needed to know something about organic chemistry before graduating from FES, and also needed to know how to understand what I read in the newspaper. I think the analytical framework presented in this class - how to describe a pollutant, what characterizes it, how to deal with it, how to think about legislation and the next generation of pollutants - was a really useful thing to learn, no matter what the topic was.
science course, chemistry.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I thought it would be relevant to my area of study and I wanted some hard science background.

Because I have a solid chemistry background and I'm interested in pollution and water quality issues but I hadn't taken an organic chemistry class before so I thought it would be an appropriate class to take.
Wanted to understand pollutants in the environment.
See above. Also very excited to learn more hard science while at FES. This is one of the few courses offered especially since biogeochem will not be available next fall.

I struggled through organic chemistry in undergrad because it was all memorization and theory - this class helped me remember and better understand the o-chem concepts because it's in context of something realistic (pollution).
to learn about organic pollutants in the environment and how to evaluate potential remediation efforts and the transport of pollutants in the environment.
Shimi is awesome and the topic really interested me.
I was looking for an introduction to organic chem.
it is relevant for my work

I took Biogeochemistry last semester, and had two Aha-moments - Gabe pointed to the entire last section of the spreadsheet of major components of the biogeochemical cycle, heavy metals, and other pollutants, and said, take Shimi's class if you want to know about these. Then, one of our field trips took us to the Pfizer clean up site, where I realized that I understood nothing of what they were talking about - I didn't have the slightest idea of how organic pollutants were created and dealt with and what the problem with them was, and what those names even meant. Now, after taking this class, I have a very useful basic framework to store information in, which helps me understand the world around me much better. I can easily retrieve information and research new topics within organic pollutants, because this class provided a framework and a basic understanding of organic chemistry, applied to pollution. It's one of the most useful classes I've ever taken, because it's a self-contained unit.
interest in topic and wanted to improve my chemistry knowledge.
I am interested in site remediation so this class is about as relevant to that topic as any offered at FES. I wanted to learn about how pollutants move in the environment and what risks they pose.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
It surpassed my expectations.
Above and beyond.
Yes.
YES!
Yes! This was my favorite class this semester. I walked out with real knowledge, not just theory.
YESYESYESYESYES
Yes
Yes
Yes it did

It surpassed my expectations - I didn't think organic chemistry would be fun. I worked very hard for this class, and won't do very well grade-wise but that isn't the point - a whole new area of science was just opened up to me and I'm excited.
yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
Yes, and more.
Yes. Still a little confused about some stuff, but that's my own fault. I know a lot more now than I did at the beginning of the course.
Yes.
YESYESYESYES
Yes
Yes
yes I did, see above
Yes. I guess I might have wanted a little more information on toxicity - not a full class, just some basic principles... but oh well. there was enough material to cover.
yes and then some
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Very helpful for completing problem sets. As long as you are sure to learn all the material for yourself the working groups are a great way to form close friendships as well as to work through all the material.
Very helpful to work through the problem sets together.
We spent a lot of time on the problem sets, working in groups - we got pretty good about it, too, but it was a lot of work. However, it was essential for not falling behind in the class.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it! It's great.

Definitely take this class even if it's not your main field of interest because it covers important and relevant material and it was one of the most enjoyable and well-taught classes I have taken at FES so far.

Block out extra time for the problem sets. Treat the TA's office hours like another mandatory class session. It will get a lot harder after the 1st quiz, so plan on spending more time on the course work as the semester progresses.

Find study partners. Talk through the problem sets with each other and enjoy the challenge! Read Shimi's very good class notes after each class to help identify questions and problem areas sooner instead of later.Begin studying for the midterm and final as early as possible!Good luck!
Don't miss any class, use TA sessions and you'll learn more than you thought was possible.
It is helpful to have some chemistry background, though not necessary.

If you are interested in pollution, remediation, chemistry, the environment - any one of two of these things - take this course. you will learn a lot about things we use everyday, and be able to make sense of many current challenges with respect to pollution.
Do the readings and keep up with the problem sets... don't procrastinate!

Do the reading and go over Shimi's lecture notes each week so you're sure you fully understand the material. If you're new to organic chem, the problem sets will take some time to get through, so be prepared to spend a good chunk of time on them every week.

Utilize all the hours the instructor offers; you will get excellent notes from the instructor so spend as much time as possible listening in class as you jot down the things that are absolutely necessary; read the notes as they come out, accumulating till exam time-- you will be in trouble. Thank goodness there are problems sets every week, they are actually a saviour, minimizing stress when it is mid term time
Don't fall behind. Do all the reading. On time. Try to get as much time with Shimi as you can. Absolutely take this class, even if you're not into chemistry.
The work is intense, but it's worth it. Go to all of the help sessions you can.
Be prepared to do detailed chemistry. Seek extra help if you need it.
